constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Overall subjective and objective quality of sleep including restfulness, depth, and restorative value

constructs.name: sleep_onset_latency
constructs.description: Time required to fall asleep after intending to sleep - longer latency indicates difficulty initiating sleep

constructs.name: sleep_continuity
constructs.description: Degree to which sleep is uninterrupted throughout the night, absence of awakenings

constructs.name: circadian_alignment
constructs.description: Degree to which sleep timing aligns with internal biological clock and natural light-dark cycle

constructs.name: pre_sleep_cognitive_arousal
constructs.description: Mental activation before bed including racing thoughts, rumination, worry, and inability to quiet the mind

constructs.name: pre_sleep_physical_arousal
constructs.description: Physical activation state before bed including muscle tension, elevated heart rate, and bodily restlessness

constructs.name: evening_screen_exposure
constructs.description: Exposure to electronic screens and blue light in the 2-3 hours before intended sleep

constructs.name: morning_light_exposure
constructs.description: Exposure to bright light, especially natural sunlight, in the first few hours after waking

constructs.name: physical_activity_level
constructs.description: Amount and intensity of physical exercise and movement during the day

constructs.name: caffeine_intake
constructs.description: Consumption of caffeine from coffee, tea, energy drinks, or other sources throughout the day

constructs.name: alcohol_consumption
constructs.description: Consumption of alcoholic beverages, especially in evening hours

constructs.name: daily_stress_level
constructs.description: Overall psychological stress, pressure, and emotional burden experienced during the day

constructs.name: sleep_schedule_consistency
constructs.description: Regularity of sleep and wake times compared to recent patterns and intended schedule

constructs.name: bedroom_environment_quality
constructs.description: Quality of sleep environment including temperature, darkness, noise level, mattress comfort, and air quality

constructs.name: daytime_napping
constructs.description: Sleep episodes taken during daytime hours that reduce homeostatic sleep pressure

constructs.name: evening_meal_timing
constructs.description: Timing of last meal relative to bedtime and heaviness of evening food consumption

constructs.name: chronotype
constructs.description: Biological predisposition toward morningness or eveningness affecting preferred sleep timing

constructs.name: trait_anxiety
constructs.description: Stable individual tendency toward anxiety, worry, and hypervigilance

constructs.name: age
constructs.description: Chronological age affecting sleep architecture, duration needs, and sleep maintenance

edges.description: Longer time to fall asleep reduces overall sleep quality and sleep satisfaction
Better sleep continuity with fewer awakenings leads to more restorative and deeper sleep
Sleeping in alignment with circadian rhythm optimizes sleep architecture and hormonal processes
Optimal bedroom conditions directly enhance subjective and objective sleep quality
Racing thoughts, worry, and mental activation make it harder to transition to sleep
Physical tension and sympathetic activation delay the onset of sleep
Caffeine blocks adenosine receptors, directly interfering with sleep initiation
When sleep timing matches circadian phase, melatonin facilitates easier sleep onset
Daytime naps discharge homeostatic sleep pressure, making nighttime sleep onset harder
Alcohol disrupts REM sleep and causes rebound awakenings as it metabolizes
Elevated physical arousal leads to more fragmented and lighter sleep throughout the night
Environmental disturbances like noise, light intrusion, and temperature cause awakenings
Heavy late meals cause digestive discomfort and acid reflux disrupting sleep
Aging is associated with lighter sleep stages and increased nighttime awakenings
Bright morning light is the primary zeitgeber that entrains the circadian clock
Blue light from screens suppresses melatonin production and delays circadian phase
Regular sleep-wake times strengthen and stabilize circadian entrainment
Individual chronotype determines natural sleep timing preferences and ease of alignment
Stressful days generate worry and rumination that persists into bedtime
Stimulating screen content and social media increase mental activation before bed
High trait anxiety amplifies nightly rumination and worry about the next day
Poor sleep creates worry about sleep itself perpetuating the problem
Regular exercise promotes parasympathetic tone and physical relaxation by evening
Caffeine increases physiological arousal, heart rate, and muscle tension
Chronic stress activates the HPA axis maintaining elevated physical arousal
Heavy late meals increase metabolic activity and physical discomfort
While initially sedating, alcohol metabolism increases physical arousal and sweating
Mental worry triggers the stress response, increasing physical tension and activation
Stress drives escapism and coping through screen-based distraction and entertainment
Poor sleep depletes emotional regulation resources and amplifies stress reactivity
High trait anxiety magnifies perception of daily stressors and threat
Morning light exposure improves mood regulation and reduces cortisol reactivity throughout the day
Poor sleep reduces energy, motivation, and capacity for physical exercise
Age affects baseline physical activity capacity and exercise patterns
Poor sleep drives compensatory caffeine use to maintain daytime alertness
Poor nighttime sleep creates daytime sleepiness prompting naps
Poor sleep may lead to sleeping in, irregular schedules, or social jet lag
Extreme chronotypes may struggle to maintain schedules aligned with social demands
Poor sleep may lead to self-medicating with alcohol to aid sleep initiation
High stress increases likelihood of evening alcohol use for relaxation
Poor sleep leads to sleeping in and reduced morning outdoor activity, limiting light exposure
High stress leads to irregular eating patterns, stress eating, or late meals due to work demands
